title: Best toilet-friendly cycling shorts 2023: Buyer’s guide to comfort break bib shorts
content:
Cyclist
Best toilet-friendly cycling shorts 2023: Buyer’s guide to comfort break bib shorts

Comfort break bib shorts are a great solution for toilet stops while out on a ride. Whether you need to go to the loo discretely at the side of a road or you don’t want to strip off all your upper layers in the cafe stop rest room, a comfort break feature is ideal for reducing overall faff.

As a relatively new concept, and only now featuring regularly on women’s bib shorts and tights, there are many variations in design, with different designs working best for different people.

We’ve tried and tested a wide collection of the most popular comfort break bib shorts to help you decide which will work best for you. Keep reading to see our recommendations for the best comfort break bib shorts.

Best comfort break bib shorts

  1. Castelli Unlimited cargo bib shorts: RRP £135 – Buy Now from Wheelbase for £131.99
  2. Petrichor Projects women’s bib shorts: RRP £149 – Buy Now from Petrichor for £149
  3. SQ Lab SQ-Short One12 women’s bib shorts: RRP £170 – Buy Now from SQ Lab for £170
  4. Albion ABR1 pocket bib shorts: RRP £145 – Buy Now from Albion for £145
  5. 7 mesh WK3 cargo bib shorts: RRP £160 – Buy now from 7mesh for £160
  6. Endura women’s GV500 Reiver bib shorts: RRP £139.99 – Buy now from Wiggle for £111.99
  7. Velocio women’s Utility bib shorts: RRP £239 – Buy Now from Velocio for £239
  8. Universal Colours Mono women’s bib shorts: RRP £120 – Buy Now from Universal Colours for £120
  9. Pactimo women’s Summit Classic bib shorts: RRP £165 – Buy Now from Pactimo for £165
  10. Lusso women’s Comfort break bib shorts: RRP £100 – Buy Now from Lusso for £100
  11. POC Ultimate VPDs bib shorts: RRP £180 – Buy Now from POC for £180
  12. Assos UMA GTV bib shorts C2: RRP £210 – Buy Now from Wiggle for £193

How do you pee in cycling shorts? Comfort break features explained

Comfort break features can appear under a variety of different names – toilet break, nature break, drop tail to name a few – but the premise is the same: cycling bibs where the back of the shorts can be pulled down to allow the rider to go to the toilet without having to take off the bib straps.

This is useful for a number of reasons, namely less hassle when you need the loo. A well executed comfort break feature means the rider won’t need to remove any upper layers to go to the toilet – handy when it’s very cold – and is quicker and easier for emergency pee stops while out on a ride.

Best women’s bib shorts: A buyer’s guide to the best bibs for cycling

In this sense it also promotes dignity and safety, with riders not needing to strip off the majority of their clothes to use the loo. It’s worth mentioning that comfort break features are typically found on women’s bib shorts.

Many of them have similar basic functions, with highly elasticated bib straps and rear panels that allow the fabric to be pulled down easily, and others go as far as integrating disconnecting straps or using crossover designs.

How do we test and why trust our advice?

At Cyclist, not only do we love riding bikes but we also love kit that makes riding bikes more practical. Our team, led by tech editor Sam Challis and web editor Matthew Loveridge, has tested a wide range of cycling kit so know what to look for, as well as what to avoid.

All of the bib shorts we’ve mentioned have been tried and tested by our female writers, both for the comfort break usability and the overall quality of the bib shorts. These are our honest opinions based on extensive testing, and we truly believe in the products we’ve recommended.

Best comfort break bib shorts

1. Castelli Unlimited cargo bib shorts

RRP: £135
Highlights: Great break feature on women’s version, Pockets, Quality chamois, Price
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Black, Gunmetal grey

The Castelli Unlimited cargo bib shorts are one of our two favourite comfort break bib shorts. The cross strap design is highly elasticated and pulls down easily, while the overall fit is high waisted and very comfortable.

An added bonus is that the bib shorts have cargo pockets for easy-access storage as well as a thick long distance-focussed chamois. Though designed for gravel/adventure riding, these are our go-to bib shorts for any riding over an hour.

  • Read our full Castelli Unlimited cargo bib shorts review

2. Petrichor Projects women’s bib shorts

RRP: £149
Highlights: Clever comfort break design, Pocket, Comfortable chamois, Smooth, flattering fabric
Sizes available: XXS – XXXL Colours available: Black

The Petrichor Projects bib shorts are up there with the Castellis for comfort, though function quite differently. The comfort break feature uses a magnetic clasp on one of the straps, which detaches to allow the rear panel to be dropped. The strap has an added loop which allows you to locate and reconnect it easily.

They also have a pocket on the right leg, as well as an excellent chamois. Bonus points for being a woman-owned independent brand.

  • Buy now from Petrichor Projects
  • Read our full Petrichor Projects women’s bib shorts review

3. SQ Lab SQ-Short One12 women’s bib shorts

RRP: £170.00
Highlights: High support chamois, Effective comfort break design, Accurate ergonomic fit
Sizes available: XS – XXL Colours available: Black

The SQ Lab bib shorts follow the traditional cross strap design, but the straps extend past the rear panel. This added length provides added support while wearing the bib shorts, preventing the rear panel from sitting loose, while giving plenty of stretch for the feature to be used.

The sizing is accurate, with a compressive but unrestricted fit, and the chamois is impressive – it has a maximum thickness of 5mm but is pre-compressed and highly effective on long rides.

  • Buy now from SQ Lab
  • Read our full SQ Lab SQ-Short One12 women’s bib shorts review

4. Albion ABR1 pocket bib shorts

RRP: £145
Highlights: Comfortable cut, Highly stretchy, Effective comfort break design, Great pockets
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Black

The Albion ABR1 bib shorts are fully designed for long-distance riding, with a rear pocket for storing jackets or layers and two side pockets for on-the-go essentials. The fabric is incredibly soft on the skin and highly stretchy, great for spending multiple hours on and around the bike.

The bib straps are wide and secure and the lower panel stretches effectively to provide a simple yet effective comfort break feature. They are also made largely from recycled materials, which is a plus.

  • Read our full Albion ABR1 pocket bib shorts review

5. 7 mesh WK3 cargo bib shorts

RRP: £160
Highlights: Pockets, Comfort break feature, High quality fabric, Good leg length
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Peat, black, midnight blue

The 7mesh WK3 bib shorts continue the comfort break/cargo pocket crossover, with four pockets – two on the back and one on each leg. The fabric sits nicely against the skin and we liked to overall cut and leg length.

The rear straps connect to the side of the shorts rather than the back, allowing for a wider section of fabric to pull down which might be easier for some, though the straps themselves did feel a tad flimsy though we experienced no actual issues with them.

  • Buy now from 7mesh
  • Read our full 7 mesh WK3 cargo bib shorts review

6. Endura women’s GV500 Reiver bib shorts

RRP: £139.99
Highlights: Excellent comfort break feature, Supportive chamois, Pockets, Soft fabric
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Black

The Endura GV500 bib shorts feature one of our favourite comfort break features. The design cleverly uses straps that connect at the upper back which split again to allow and rejoin by overlapping at the lower back. This is great because it stops the straps sliding on the shoulders – without the need for a cross strap design – and still holds the fabric secure when the feature is not in use.

The chamois is high density and provides effective support on long rides, and there are leg pockets for storage – worth noting that these sit on the front of the leg rather than the traditional side placement. The GV500 bib shorts do run pretty small so we’d recommend sizing up at least one size.

  • Read our full Endura women’s GV500 Reiver bib shorts review

7. Velocio women’s Utility bib shorts

RRP: £239
Highlights: Highly compressive, Comfortable straps, Sizing options, Decent comfort break feature
Sizes available: XXS – XXXL Colours available: Black

The Velocio Utility bib shorts use traditional straps with an added connection at the upper back, which holds them in place when using the comfort break feature. It’s secure and easy to use, though the bib shorts do run very small so we would definitely recommend sizing up to get the most out of the shorts and the toilet break feature.

The cut itself is compressive and soft, and there is a wide range of sizing options to choose from.

  • Buy now from Velocio
  • Read our full Velocio women’s Utility bib shorts review

8. Universal Colours Mono women’s bib shorts

RRP: £120
Highlights: Comfort break feature, Comfortable, Use of recycled fabrics, Good length, Compressive
Sizes available: XXS – XXL Colours available: Black, navy blue, lawson gold, deep red, canopy green

The Universal Colours Mono bib shorts are made using recycled materials and are designed with a compressive fit for long distance riding. We really enjoyed the compression, though would recommend it for mid-to-cool bib short weather riding as the fabric has limited breathability for really hot days.

The Mono bib shorts use the classic cross strap comfort break design, which is highly elasticated and the rear panel springs back nicely into place when no longer in use. They’re also very reasonably priced so are a good option for those looking on a tighter budget.

  • Buy now from Universal Colours
  • Read our full Universal Colours Mono women’s bib shorts review

9. Pactimo women’s Summit Classic bib shorts

RRP: £165
Highlights: Comfortable, Lightweight, Comfort break feature
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Black

The Pactimo Summit bib shorts use a hybrid comfort break system, with connecting rear straps and a cut out which is facilitated by a clip between the straps at the front. It seems strange but it works incredibly well – all you have to do is unclip at the front (which is low enough to reach under a jersey or jacket) and pull down at the back.

The fabric is lightweight and the chamois is brilliant, especially on long rides, though we personally prefer a slightly longer bib short leg than on the Summits.

  • Buy now from Pactimo
  • Read our full Pactimo women’s Summit Classic bib shorts review

10. Lusso women’s Comfort break bib shorts

RRP: £100
Highlights: Smart comfort break feature, Minimal seams, Good chamois, Breathable
Sizes available: XS – XXXL Colours available: Black

The Lusso Comfort break bib shorts do what they say on the tin. There is a secure bib strap connection at the upper back and Lusso has managed to create a highly elasticated design with the need for overlapping straps or extra security. The rear panel just pulls down and works excellently.

The bib shorts also have a high density chamois and minimal seams. The sizing is slightly off, so would recommend sizing up at least one size, but they are an impressive offering for their affordable price.

  • Buy now from Lusso
  • Read our full Lusso women’s Comfort break bib shorts review

11. Poc Ultimate VPDs bib shorts

RRP: £180
Highlights: Soft fabric, Effective chamois, Compressive legs, Comfort break option
Sizes available: XS – XL Colours available: Uranium black

The POC VPDs bib shorts are silky smooth and undoubtedly win the softest bib short fabric competition. The material has mid-level compression on the body, with more on the legs, and the chamois is medium thickness and ultra-comfortable.

The VPDs comfort break feature is simple, though perhaps overly so. It is easy to pull down but the lack of bib strap connection at the back does mean they straps can slide if you’re wearing a slippery base layer. It’s good to see the feature included on high-level kit and has little negative impact on the bib shorts overall.

  • Buy now from Tredz
  • Read our full Poc Ultimate VPDs bib shorts review

12. Assos UMA GTV bib shorts C2

RRP: £210
Highlights: Toilet break feature, Comfortable, Compressive, Decent leg length, Flattering
Sizes available: XS – XXL Colours available: Black

The Assos UMA GTV bib shorts take probably the most innovative approach to comfort break design, using two magnetised clips to detach the bib straps at the lower back. This means you’re not reliant on stretchy material alone, which can become loose over time, though does take a little getting used to. Although it can be a little fiddly, it is an effective option for those that want a fully detachable design.

The bib short fabric has a high level of compression and, paired with a reliable long distance chamois, is a good option for big days out on the bike, whether for racing or leisure.

  • Read our full Assos UMA GTV bib shorts C2 review

FAQs

Do I need a comfort break feature?

Comfort break features can be very useful for several reasons. Firstly, they’re handy for those urgent toilet stops mid-ride as they enable you to remain fully dressed and decent while still being able to pee. Secondly, they are especially useful in the winter when you don’t want to remove all of your upper layers to go to the toilet.

They’re designed to reduce faff and are a great addition to bib shorts and tights for any rider, especially those doing big days out on the bike.

How do comfort break features work?

Each comfort break feature will function slightly differently, but there are a few common trends. The most widely used system features bib straps that cross over at the back, combined with a high stretch rear panel on the shorts, which allows the bibs to be pulled down at the rear without pulling the straps off the shoulders.

Another popular design sees a connection between traditional vertical bib straps on the upper back, which serves the same purpose. Some brands also employ magnetic clips so that the straps can be disconnected on either the front or the back. No one design is categorically superior to another, and we’ve tested a range of different systems to give your our honest feedback on each style.

What to look out for in a comfort break feature

Comfort break bib shorts, like much cycling kit, can be broken down into key elements to check for, and we’ve listed a few below:

  • Strap design – look at how the comfort break feature operates. If you struggle with arm mobility, it might be best to avoid ones that require clipping and unclipping at the back. If you want a really secure design, check how the straps sit on the shoulder both while riding and when the fabric is pulled down.
  • Fit and compression – to allow the rear of the shorts to be pulled down, many brands will use looser or stretchier fabric on the lower back to facilitate this movement. If you want a really compressive fit all round, it’s worth looking at how much give that area has and if the cut is high or low waisted.
  • Sizing – it’s important to check whether a set of bib shorts run true-to-size, especially when looking at comfort break features. If you end up with a size that’s too small, it’s likely it will impact how easy the feature is to use as the area may already be reaching its maximum stretch.
  • Chamois – comfort break features are typically geared towards longer rides and as such, make sure to check out our reviews on each chamois. It’s one of the few elements that can’t really be tried before purchase so we’ve made sure to include extensive testing for each of our bib short reviews.
  • Pockets – you don’t need pockets, but we’d argue that at least one cargo pocket on long distance bib shorts is a major bonus. They provide quick and easy storage access while riding, great for snacks or your phone.

author: Charlotte Head | Tech Writer
